history.content:
If you are going to be searching for full-time hardware engineering jobs during the fall of your senior year, I would strongly recommend taking EECS 151 in the fall, either concurrent with 149, or without taking 149 at all. I think it's really important to have 151 on your resume when you're looking for those kinds of jobs (I know that in the past, Apple has actually given funding to 151 because they want more candidates for their hardware engineering roles). I think 149 prepares you more for embedded software engineering rather than for hardware engineering. If you're not planning on looking for a job that semester, then it might not be as important to take 151 in the fall.

Having taken all three classes in separate semesters, I can confirm that any combination of two of them would be pretty intense. 149 and 151 together would be bad because the final projects would coincide, but 151 and 152 together would be bad because you wouldn't get the boost in 152 from reviewing a lot of CS 61C concepts in 151. So both options are bad in different ways :) but I think it really comes down to your recruiting plans. Hope this was helpful!

children.subject: Nevermind, just read your post over again and it kind of answers that question! So, a different question, besides 151 and 152, what other courses could I be taking that will help for those type of roles?
I guess it depends on the kind of hardware job you have in mind. Are you interested more in like digital circuit design, or higher-level than that, or something else entirely?

More towards the first two you mentioned. In addition, I've taken several courses in the 12x series (Information Processing and Communication) (120, 123, and C128 to be more exact) and am interested in anything under that umbrella as well.

Honestly I'm not really sure what I would recommend. Maybe EECS 126 for communication? I have not taken it myself though. EECS 149 is definitely still a good class to take if you have enough time, but you only really have one more fall semester. I've often struggled to decide what classes to take too, despite having a lot of the same interests as you mentioned. I think part of it may have been that I was afraid of taking grad classes. Maybe some other people will chime in with their recommendations?
Thank you for the advice and sentiment anon, I'll also consider EECS 126 for the fall as well. Hopefully other people will have some insight too.

OP here! @student_response, thank you for your input! I think I'll heavily consider taking EECS 151 in the fall, then. However, that class combined with EECS 149 doesn't seem ideal. I might be willing to let that class go... what are your opinions on EECS 149 in terms of helping with hardware engineering related roles? It's too bad it's not offered in the spring...

Hi anon, when you say "sounds worse than 149+152" did you mean 149+151? Also, I think the concern with the previous anon who answered was that the coinciding projects might prove to be a bit challenging if taking 149 and 151 together, but interesting to hear an opposing opinion. How was the experience of taking two lab sections? Lastly, would you say 151+149 would be less work than 151+126?

oops yes, that's what I meant. 151+152 worse than 149+151. But for me this is because I found 152 really challenging (labs were pretty time consuming and exams were worse than any other class I've taken) BUT if you don't already have a group that you trust for at least one of the projects, then maybe don't take them together.

I spent a lot of time in Cory taking two lab sections, but it wasn't *that* bad until the very end of the semester. I felt like the exams for these 2 classes (149 and 151) were not that bad, and some of the material was pretty complementary imo

I have no clue what the workload for 126 is like, so I can't say.
Okay, thank you for the advice! Seems like content and exam wise, taking 149+151 shouldn't be *too* rough, but I'll think a little bit more about the labs and projects.

I took 151 and 149 the same semester, and it wasn't terrible (as long as you dont take anything else thats hard), and I think you taking both would look good for recruiting.
I think 152 is pretty important knowledge but taking it your last semester sounds not very fun. Personally I think 151 + 152 sounds worse than 149 + 152.

Idk if this made you more confused. If it helps I would say the 151 FPGA lab is easier than ASIC having taken both if you end up having to take 151 with another project heavy class.

history.content: For more hardware engineering related roles, which class would be best? I'll be taking one in the fall: EECS 151 or EECS 149. Ideally, I would want to take both, but split over two semesters. I know EECS 149 is only offered in the fall (from what I've seen) so I would have to take EECS 151 in the spring (most likely concurrent with CS 152). I am also a rising senior. Any thoughts?
history.subject: EECS 151 versus EECS 149
